Situation1: They travel a long distance to participate in an important religious festival, ensuring they fully engage in all rituals and offerings.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story:
I had traveled all night by bus, determined not to miss the annual festival at my ancestral temple. My family expected me to be there, to offer prayers and join in the rituals that connected us to our roots. The scent of incense and the sound of bells filled the air as I hurried through the temple gates, my mind already rehearsing the mantras I would recite. But before I could enter, I remembered my duty as a voter—today was also election day, and the polling booth was just down the street. I rushed over, wanting to fulfill my civic responsibility before returning to the festival.

At the booth, the officials announced that everyone with last names A–M must switch to a new line. My last name started with "B." The new line was longer and slower, but the officials insisted. I glanced at my watch, anxiety rising. The main ceremony at the temple would begin soon, and my absence would be noticed. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations: my family and faith on one side, my duty as a citizen on the other. I stood frozen, torn between the two worlds, feeling the pressure of both roles closing in on me.
